bibl.title: Hisayo Kuwahara v. Henry M. White. Answer and Return
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington
In the Matter of the Petition of Sakutaro Kuwahara for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
In the Matter of the Petition of Sakutaro Kuwahara for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.

Comes now Henry M. White and by way of answer to the petition for writ of habeas corpus herein and return to the show cause order heretofore entered herein on the 21st day of January, 1920, respectfully shows the court as follows, to-wit:

That this respondent, Henry M. White, is now and at all of the times herein mentioned has been, United States Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, and that the order to show cause heretofore entered herein was served on this respondent on to-wit, the 22nd day of January, 1920.

That on to-wit, the 27th day of September, 1919, one Hisayo Kuwahara, on whose behalf the petition herein has been filed, arrived at the port of Seattle on board the steamer Africa Maru from Japan of which said country the said Hisayo Kuwahara then and now is a subject. That on to-wit, the 3d day of October, 1919 a board of special inquiry was duly and regularly appointed by the Commissioner of Immigration at said Seattle, and that thereupon said October 3, 1919 a hearing was duly and regularly had before said special board of inquiry attended by the said Hisayo Kuwahara in person for the purpose of determining the right of the said Hisayo Kuwahara to land and to be admitted to the United States.

That upon such hearing having been held as aforesaid it was duly and regularly determined by said special board of inquiry that said alien Hisayo Kuwahara was a person likely to be a public charge and was not entitled to be admitted to the United States, and that the said alien should be and was thereby excluded from the United States upon said grounds and the grounds set forth in Exhibit "A" hereto attached.

That thereafter an appeal was taken from said dicision by the said alien to the Secretary of Labor and that the Secretary of Labor on to-wit, the 15th day of January, 1920, dismissed and denied said appeal and affirmed the determination and ruling of the said special board of inquiry.

That your respondent has detained the said Hisayo Kuwahara under and by virtue of the said proceedings as hereinabove referred to and set forth; that said proceedings were in all respects legal and regular and that the said alien has had a fair hearing. That a copy of said proceedings is attached hereto, marked Exhibit A and hereby made a part hereof as though fully set out herein.

WHEREFORE, respondent prays that petitioner's application and petition herein for writ of habeas corpus be denied and that said show causeorder heretofore entered herein be vacated and set aside and that said respondent have and recover from petitioner all of his costs
Attorneys for Henry M. White, United States Commissioner of Immigration.
The United States of America Western District of Washington
JOHN H. SARGENT, being first duly sworn, on his oath deposes and says: That he is Acting Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington;
That he has read the foregoing answer and return and is familiar with the contents thereof and that the facts set forth and alleged in said answer and return are true as he verily believes.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 26th day of January, A.D. 1920.
Deputy Clerk, U.S. District Court, Western District of Washington
